_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Services to Buildings and Dwellings

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Pool Chlor of Nevada, Inc. provides chlorination for recreational swimming pools in the Las Vegas, Nevada area.  Pool Chlor of Nevada has ensured a safe operation dating back to 1973.

Pool Chlor of Nevada's manager/owner is personally committed to offer superior service and to maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The owner administers the company's safety and environmental policies. He is also responsible for various inspections to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include, hazard communications, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED

Startup of the chlorine system occurred in 1973.  The process is located at 5560 Procyon Street, Las Vegas, Nevada, 89118.  The chlorine transfer process for Pool Chlor of Nevada consists of chlorine one-ton containers (maximum of 8) which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine liquid is dispensed from a one ton container through a filling manifold to 20 pound cylinders.  The system also includes a scrubber water tank.  The maximum quantity of chlorine on site is 16,000 pounds.  The filling station is located outside under a canopy.  Misters are used to cool the chlorine containers during high temperatures.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Pool Chlor of Nevada has a Process Safety Management program in place to manage the handling of chlorine.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute and the National Association of Gas Chlorinators.  In addition to the Management Programs, there is a scrubber system that is used to neutr

alize displaced chlorine gas while transferring chlorine liquid.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The five year accident history investigation (June 1999 - June 2004) revealed that there has been no reportable release of chlorine at the facility.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

If a release of chlorine were to occur, Pool Chlor of Nevada's action plan is to call 911 in order to reach the local emergency responders.  Employees will evacuate the facility to a point that is upwind of the hazard.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  The emergency action plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, and to ensure that the plan is kept current.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Pool Chlor of Nevada has conducted a PSM/RMP Compliance Audit (September 2002) and revalidated the Process Hazard Analysis (April 2004).  All recommendations from the audit were addressed by August 2003.  All recommendations resulting from the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation have an estimated completion date of December 2004. 

The Process Safety Management team will continue to provide a safe environment by ensuring employee involvement in safety development and training.
